International Restrictions:
*Entry to Ecuador: The land border with Peru remains closed. However, Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents may be allowed to enter Ecuador, via the Huaquillas southern border checkpoint. The land border with Colombia opened in December 2021 to all travellers, but only through the ‘Rumichaca’ international checkpoint, from 8am to 5pm.
Most ports remain closed for travel/tourism activities. As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are permitted in Esmeraldas, Guayaquil, Manta and Puerto Baquerizo ports.
International commercial flights are operating to and from Ecuador. However, we highly recommend you to contact your airline/travel company to check your travel itinerary, in case of any last minute COVID-19-related changes.
As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are authorised at the following ports: Esmeraldas, Manta, Guayaquil and Puerto Bolivar. However, there are strict guidelines and measures to comply with to obtain the relevant permissions.
*Testing / screening on arrival: Upon arrival in Ecuador, all passengers are required to complete a Health Declaration Form with their itinerary and local contact details.
Travellers over 16 years old must present their full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses), received at least 14 days prior the flight date, and a negative antigen or Real-Time Qualitative Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-qPCR) test, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding their flight.
Passengers between 2 and 16 years old (15 years, 11 months and 29 days) must present a negative RT-qPCR or antigen test, taken 72 hours before the flight.
The use of Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review. See Demonstrating your COVID-19 status.
Passengers in transit are subject to the same requirements as those entering Ecuador. You should arrange to take a private test.
Only children under 2 years old are exempt from the RT-qPCR or antigen test and the COVID-19 vaccination certificate requirement. Airline crew members are also exempt from the above requirements.
If, on arrival, a passenger presents COVID-19 related symptoms, they will be evaluated by a Ministry of Public Health (MSP) representative, prior to entering the immigration control area. Suspected cases of COVID-19 will be required to take a rapid antigen test. If the result is positive, the passenger will be instructed to self-isolate for 10 days. Passengers arriving from countries whose regulations state that COVID-19 vaccination is available only after 6 months of having been infected, and who are thus unable to show their full vaccination certificate, will be required to present together with their COVID-19 infection certificate, an official document proving the above dispensation and regulation (valid for 6 months) and a negative RT-PCR test.
Visitors previously diagnosed with COVID-19 and who continue to test positive with an RT-PCR test after a month, should present a a medical certificate issued in the country of origin which indicates that they are non-infectious. This will be accepted as long as they are no longer showing symptoms.
Passengers with a medical dispensation for COVID-19 vaccination must present a a valid medical certificate and a negative RT-PCR test.
*Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: Ecuador will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
*Quarantine requirements: Passengers who test positive in the antigen test taken at the airport will need to self-isolate for 10 days, from the date of the test. Self-isolation for non-residents can be carried out in any hotel, at their own expense. The contact number of, and full address at which the passenger will self-isolate should be included in the Health Status Declaration Form. Compliance with the isolation requirement and the passenger’s state of health will be monitored via telephone calls.
Local residents and people qualified as “priority attention groups” such as people over 65 years old, children and pregnant women, will be allowed to self-isolate at their homes.
The Ministry of Public Health has published more information on coronavirus protocols that also allows for direct messaging with the Ministry (Spanish only).
If you need to find emergency accommodation to go through the mandatory self-isolation protocol, you can access options on the Ministry of Public Health website
The Government will monitor the situation in other countries with high risk of contagion to prevent incoming flights.
Travel to and from the Galapagos: Tourist activities are allowed in the Galapagos Islands.
All travellers over 16 years old wishing to enter the Islands must present a negative RT-qPCR or antigen test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior to the date of the flight to the Galapagos Islands, along with a full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses, or its equivalent), received at least 14 days prior the flight date. The use of “Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards” from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review. See ‘Demonstrating your COVID-19 status’
Children between 2 and 16 years must present a negative RT-qPCR or antigen test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior embarking the flight.
Any passengers presenting COVID-19 related symptoms will be denied entry to the Islands.National and foreign tourists must also present evidence of a return flight, as well as the Galapagos Transit Control Card, to be filled out online at least 24 hours before the flight. Travel health insurance is mandatory for foreign tourists.
For inter-island travel, all passengers over 12 years must present their complete vaccination certificate.


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Ecuador: The Ecuadorean government provides coronavirus-related information on the Coronavirus Ecuador website. The Ministry of Public Health (MSP) also provides an information page. However, the most up to date information is accessible via their Twitter account.
*Restrictions: The general nationwide biosecurity measures include:
mandatory COVID-19 vaccination for Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents
extra precaution advised for the elderly and vulnerable
mandatory use of face masks in public spaces
social distancing measures, frequent hand washing and appropriate venilation
in-person school classes were suspended in 2020, however most are now taking place again.
remote working continues to be encouraged
the reopening of beaches will continue to be monitored via the “Distancia2” app
a nationwide tracing app ( ̔ASI Ecuador̕ ) is available to alert people if they have been in contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case during the last 15 days. The app is supported via Bluetooth and maintains the confidentiality of users
the land border with Peru remains closed until further notice.
However, Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents may be allowed to enter Ecuador via the Huaquillas southern border checkpoint
the land border with Colombia opened on 17 December 2021 to all travellers, but only through the ‘Rumichaca’ international check-point, from 8am to 5pm. Standard entry requirements apply.
most ports remain closed for travel/tourism activities. As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are permitted in Esmeraldas, Guayaquil, Manta and Puerto Baquerizo ports
All people over 12 (including foreign tourists) must present their COVID-19 vaccination card (showing 2 complete doses) to enter any establishment providing non-essential services (for example, but not limited to, banks, shops, supermarkets, restaurants, transport, etc). This rule has also been enforced at airports. This will not apply to public sector institutions and for essential services such as health and education. COVID-19 vaccination certificates are also mandatory for all passengers over 5 years old for all inter-district, interstate, urban and tourist buses.
Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee continues to urge local authorities to implement biosecurity measures.
Please note that COE only makes recommendations, but the power to impose these restrictions rests with local authorities. As a result, you may see some discrepancies between local areas.
The central government’s ‘red, yellow, green’ alert system indicates epidemiological risk, and recommends associated restrictions for high, medium and low risk levels. The district traffic light colours will change weekly.
*Red:
maximum public attendance capacity of 30% in markets, financial and government establishments. 30 % capacity indoors in shopping centres, supermarkets, restaurants, cinemas, theatres (sale and consumption of food and drinks not permitted), gyms, saunas/steam rooms and spas. 50% maximum capacity outdoors.
Bars, karaokes, and night clubs at 30% maximum capacity.
50% maximum attendance at beaches, parks and open spaces. Large scale events are prohibited.
all passengers must be seated on public transport
voluntary in-person classes for higher education establishments
maximum 50% capacity for in person preschool education with 50% maximum capacity for in-person classes
online classes for primary school education
maximum capacity of 50% for in person working, except for strategic sectors. Same recommendation for private entities
*Yellow:
maximum public attendance capacity of 60% inside shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments , restaurants, cinemas, theatres (the sale and consumption of food and drinks is not permitted), gyms, saunas/steam rooms, and spas. Outdoor capacity is recommended at 85%.
50% maximum capacity in indoor areas at bars, karaokes and night clubs. 60% outdoorss.
75% maximum attendance at beaches, parks and open spaces.
all passengers must be seated on public transport
in person classes for higher education establishments to be voluntary
maximum 50% capacity for in person preschool education
primary school education to be voluntary
maximum 75% capacity for in person working for public and private sectors, except for strategic sectors.
*Green:
maximum public attendance capacity of 85% in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments. 85% indoors restaurants, cinemas, theatres (the sale and consumption food and drinks is not permitted), gyms, saunas/steam rooms and spas. No restrictions outdoors.
maximum capacity of 85% in bars, karaokes and night clubs.
100% attendance at beaches, parks and open spaces.
public transport with all seated passengers
100% in-person classes for high education establishments
preschool education with 50% maximum capacity for in-person classes
voluntary in-person primary school education
no restrictions on in person working.
Further local restrictions, including vehicle circulation restrictions, are the responsibility of local authorities. These restrictions may change at short notice and vary between different areas, so check regularly for updates (see details below, including the restrictions in place in Quito). The most up to date information can be found via the local authorities’ social media channels:
Quito: @MunicipioQuito; Guayaquil: @alcaldiagye; Cuenca: @MunicipioCuenca; Galapagos: @CGGalapagos
Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee (COE) has a website with their official resolutions (Spanish only).
During the national health emergency, the Ecuadorean Ministry of Health will continue to issue the required health prevention measures, including PCR tests and any mandatory self-isolation (Aislamiento Preventivo Obligatorio – APO) requirements.
Visit the Quito “Mariscal Sucre” International Airport website for details on their COVID-19 protocols and health measures for passengers.
Visit the Guayaquil “Jose Joaquin de Olmedo” International Airport website for general information on COVID-19 measures and related FAQ (in Spanish).
*Restrictions in Quito: In addition to adhering to the standard general biosecurity measures, you must also carry an identity card at all times.
The “Pico y Placa” system for restricting private vehicle use was reinstated from 4 November 2021.Vehicles with number plates ending in the following numbers will have restrictions on the given days below, and will not be allowed to circulate from 6am to 9.30am and from 4pm to 9pm on the assigned days: Monday: 0, 1; Tuesday: 2, 3; Wednesday 4, 5; Thursday 6, 7 and Friday 8, 9.
There are no vehicle restrictions at the weekends or on official public holidays. “Pico y Placa” does not apply to over 65 year-olds who drive their own vehicle.
